elements.content: A layered metal–organic framework (MOF) comprising extra-large nanographene sheets, HBC MOF, was successfully synthesized using a dicarboxylic acid derivative of hexa-peri-hexabenzocoronene (HBCLH2), and its structure was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystal structure shows that 2D layers composed of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit and HBCL are located on top of each other through multiple weak interlayer bonds, affording HBC MOF, having three dimensionally connected nanopores with large nanographene surfaces. The HBC-based nanographene sheets are anchored to the MOF framework via two zinc carboxylate linkages and therefore have an axial rotational freedom. The sorption isotherms of gaseous molecules such as carbon dioxide and hydrocarbons (acetylene, propane, propylene, benzene, and cyclohexane) on HBC MOF all displayed a hysteretic profile with reversible structural changes, as observed by in situ powder X-ray diffraction studies.
elements.clean_text: A layered metal-organic framework (MOF) comprising extra-large nanographene sheets,  HBC  MOF, was successfully synthesized using a dicarboxylic acid derivative of hexa-peri-hexabenzocoronene (HBCLH2), and its structure was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The crystal structure shows that 2D layers composed of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit and HBCL are located on top of each other through multiple weak interlayer bonds, affording  HBC  MOF, having three dimensionally connected nanopores with large nanographene surfaces. The HBC-based nanographene sheets are anchored to the MOF framework via two zinc carboxylate linkages and therefore have an axial rotational freedom. The sorption isotherms of gaseous molecules such as carbon dioxide and hydrocarbons (acetylene, propane, propylene, benzene, and cyclohexane) on  HBC  MOF all displayed a hysteretic profile with reversible structural changes, as observed by in situ powder X-ray diffraction studies.

elements.content: Since the ancient Egyptian era, porous carbons such as activated carbons have been widely used for thousands of years as adsorbents, catalysts, etc. Despite their remarkable utility, porous carbons are chemically and structurally elusive with a large pore-size distribution. Recently, discrete nanographenes with extended π-conjugated structures have become available. Although tailoring of structurally defined porous carbons is difficult, one may fabricate porous nanocarbon analogues if such discrete nanographenes are properly assembled in a three-dimensional manner. However, reported examples of self-assembled nanographenes mostly utilize their strong π–π interaction, so that the resulting structures barely possess any open π surface.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the ancient Egyptian era, porous carbons such as activated carbons have been widely used for thousands of years as adsorbents, catalysts, etc. Despite their remarkable utility, porous carbons are chemically and structurally elusive with a large pore-size distribution. Recently, discrete nanographenes with extended π-conjugated structures have become available. Although tailoring of structurally defined porous carbons is difficult, one may fabricate porous nanocarbon analogues if such discrete nanographenes are properly assembled in a three-dimensional manner. However, reported examples of self-assembled nanographenes mostly utilize their strong π-π interaction, so that the resulting structures barely possess any open π surface.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) provide a promising platform for creating porous crystalline structures. Thus, if a nanographene is used as a metal-coordination ligand, one may construct porous nanocarbon analogues using MOF frameworks. In fact, certain nanographene-based MOFs have been synthesized using perylene, corannulene, and coronene as ligands. More recently, Zhou and co-workers reported a new nanographene-based MOF, where Zr4+ ions are bridged by a large hexa-peri-hexabenzocoronene (HBC) derivative carrying six carboxylic acid groups, and demonstrated the interesting potential of such a porous nanocarbon analogue as a photocatalyst for the reduction of CO2 with visible light. They tried to tactically overcome the low solubility of the HBC family by a stepwise synthetic approach, where a precursor MOF with soluble hexaphenylbenzene ligands was prepared and then oxidatively converted by a “single crystal” to “single crystal” transition into the HBC-based MOF. In the resulting MOF, the HBC units are rigidly anchored via six carboxylate groups to the MOF framework.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) provide a promising platform for creating porous crystalline structures. Thus, if a nanographene is used as a metal-coordination ligand, one may construct porous nanocarbon analogues using MOF frameworks. In fact, certain nanographene-based MOFs have been synthesized using perylene, corannulene, and coronene as ligands. More recently, Zhou and co-workers reported a new nanographene-based MOF, where Zr4+ ions are bridged by a large hexa-peri-hexabenzocoronene (HBC) derivative carrying six carboxylic acid groups, and demonstrated the interesting potential of such a porous nanocarbon analogue as a photocatalyst for the reduction of CO2 with visible light. They tried to tactically overcome the low solubility of the HBC family by a stepwise synthetic approach, where a precursor MOF with soluble hexaphenylbenzene ligands was prepared and then oxidatively converted by a "single crystal" to "single crystal" transition into the HBC-based MOF. In the resulting MOF, the HBC units are rigidly anchored via six carboxylate groups to the MOF framework.

elements.content: Herein, we report a new HBC-based MOF ( HBC MOF), which is certainly located on an opposite extreme of that developed by the group of Zhou in the sense that the constituent HBC units possibly bear an axial rotational freedom (HBCLH2, ). One more thing to note is that its synthetic protocol includes only one step (), which is made possible by avoiding the intrinsic solubility problem of HBC with bulky mesityl groups attached to its periphery.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a new HBC-based MOF ( HBC  MOF), which is certainly located on an opposite extreme of that developed by the group of Zhou in the sense that the constituent HBC units possibly bear an axial rotational freedom (HBCLH2, ). One more thing to note is that its synthetic protocol includes only one step (), which is made possible by avoiding the intrinsic solubility problem of HBC with bulky mesityl groups attached to its periphery.

elements.content: Synthetic scheme for a HBC-based ligand (HBCLH2). Top and side views of the X-ray crystal structure of HBCLH2 are shown next to its chemical structure. The thermal ellipsoids are scaled to the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms in the top and side views and the mesityl groups in the side view are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic scheme for a HBC-based ligand (HBCLH2). Top and side views of the X-ray crystal structure of HBCLH2 are shown next to its chemical structure. The thermal ellipsoids are scaled to the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms in the top and side views and the mesityl groups in the side view are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Synthetic scheme for HBC MOFs using Zn2+ and HBCLH2. A microscopic image features a single crystal of HBC MOF-1. HBC MOF-1, HBC MOF-2, and HBC MOF-3 are interconvertible upon removal and uptake of guest molecules (DEF and water). DEF denotes N,N-diethylformamide.
elements.clean_text: 2  Synthetic scheme for  HBC  MOFs using Zn2+ and HBCLH2. A microscopic image features a single crystal of  HBC  MOF-1.  HBC  MOF-1,  HBC  MOF-2, and  HBC  MOF-3 are interconvertible upon removal and uptake of guest molecules (DEF and water). DEF denotes N,N-diethylformamide.

elements.content: For the synthesis of HBCLH2, the borylated tetramesityl HBC 1 was subjected to Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling with methyl 4-bromobenzoate, affording the ester-protected ligand HBCLMe2. Then, this compound was subjected to alkaline hydrolysis to yield HBCLH2, which was unambiguously characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry, and crystallographic analysis. A single crystal of HBCLH2, suitable for X-ray crystallography (Table S4), was obtained by slow evaporation of its DMSO-d 6 solution at 25 °C. As shown in , the crystal structure indicates that the carboxylic acid groups are located at both ends of the HBC core at a distance of ca. 23 Å. The HBC moiety is planar, with its calculated mean plane deviation of 0.11 Å ( and Figure S6). The dihedral angle between the HBC core and the connected phenylene moiety was evaluated to be 35.9° (Figure S7). Prior to the synthesis of HBC MOF, we tested the solubility of HBCLH2 at 25 °C and found that the maximum concentration available for its N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) solution was roughly 15 mM, which is sufficiently high for the construction of HBC MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

For the synthesis of HBCLH2, the borylated tetramesityl HBC 1  was subjected to Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling with methyl 4-bromobenzoate, affording the ester-protected ligand HBCLMe2. Then, this compound was subjected to alkaline hydrolysis to yield HBCLH2, which was unambiguously characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry, and crystallographic analysis. A single crystal of HBCLH2, suitable for X-ray crystallography (Table S4), was obtained by slow evaporation of its DMSO-d 6 solution at 25 °C. As shown in , the crystal structure indicates that the carboxylic acid groups are located at both ends of the HBC core at a distance of ca. 23 Å. The HBC moiety is planar, with its calculated mean plane deviation of 0.11 Å ( and Figure S6). The dihedral angle between the HBC core and the connected phenylene moiety was evaluated to be 35.9° (Figure S7). Prior to the synthesis of  HBC  MOF, we tested the solubility of HBCLH2 at 25 °C and found that the maximum concentration available for its N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) solution was roughly 15 mM, which is sufficiently high for the construction of  HBC  MOF.

elements.content: HBC MOF-1 was synthesized by the reaction of HBCLH2 with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in DEF for 3 days at 25 °C, and yellow rhombic crystals of HBC MOF-1, [Zn­(HBCL)­(H2O)­(DEF)7] n , suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis, were obtained (). The crystal structure of HBC MOF-1 ( and Tables S1 and S2) showed that the dinuclear Zn2+ complex units are connected together by HBCL through the coordination of its carboxylate groups (a), affording an infinite metal–organic layer (b-I). This layer includes two crystallographically nonequivalent HBCL (HBCL1 and HBCL2, b). The carboxylate groups in HBCL1 and HBCL2 coordinate to the Zn2+ ions with a tetrahedral geometry in monodentate and bidentate bridging modes, respectively, where the dinuclear Zn2+ complex units showed a positional disorder with occupancies of 0.8 and 0.2 for two sites (Figure S5). The π planes of the HBC moieties in HBCL1 and HBCL2 retain their planar structure with calculated mean plane deviations of 0.034 and 0.10 Å, respectively (Figure S6). The centroids of HBCL1 and HBCL2 are apart from each other by 24.0 and 16.7 Å, affording a parallelogram grid (b-I). Such layers are located on top of each other with an interlayer distance of 7.47 Å (b-II) and a lateral offset of 17.5 Å (Figure S10a), affording HBC MOF-1 having three dimensionally connected nanopores. clearly visualizes that two DEF molecules are adsorbed via multiple CH−π interactions onto the π plane of the HBC moiety in HBCL2. The layered structure of HBC MOF-1 was supported by multiple weak interlayer bonds such as (1) CH−π bonds (2.68 and 2.72 Å) between two hydrogen atoms of a benzoate unit in HBCL2 and two aromatic rings of the mesityl groups in HBCL1 in an adjacent layer and (2) a CH–O bond (2.74 Å) between a hydrogen atom in a methyl group of the mesityl unit in HBCL1 and an oxygen atom in the carboxylate group of HBCL1 in an adjacent layer (Figure S11a). The three dimensionally connected nanopores adopt a zigzag shape with maximum and minimum cross sections of 12.9 × 9.3 and 4.3 × 3.3 Å2, respectively (c and Figures S12 and S13). Furthermore, the volume of its solvent-accessible void was calculated to be 19% of the total volume. Interestingly, the large π planes of the HBC moieties in HBCL are not stacked together but exposed to the interior void of the nanopore, where a 1 cm3 single crystal of HBC MOF-1 is estimated to provide a total π surface area of 4.5 × 102 m2.
elements.clean_text: HBC  MOF-1 was synthesized by the reaction of HBCLH2 with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DEF for 3 days at 25 °C, and yellow rhombic crystals of  HBC  MOF-1, [Zn(HBCL)(H2O)(DEF)7] n , suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis, were obtained (). The crystal structure of  HBC  MOF-1 ( and Tables S1 and S2) showed that the dinuclear Zn2+ complex units are connected together by HBCL through the coordination of its carboxylate groups (a), affording an infinite metal-organic layer (b-I). This layer includes two crystallographically nonequivalent HBCL (HBCL1 and HBCL2, b). The carboxylate groups in HBCL1 and HBCL2 coordinate to the Zn2+ ions with a tetrahedral geometry in monodentate and bidentate bridging modes, respectively, where the dinuclear Zn2+ complex units showed a positional disorder with occupancies of 0.8 and 0.2 for two sites (Figure S5). The π planes of the HBC moieties in HBCL1 and HBCL2 retain their planar structure with calculated mean plane deviations of 0.034 and 0.10 Å, respectively (Figure S6). The centroids of HBCL1 and HBCL2 are apart from each other by 24.0 and 16.7 Å, affording a parallelogram grid (b-I). Such layers are located on top of each other with an interlayer distance of 7.47 Å (b-II) and a lateral offset of 17.5 Å (Figure S10a), affording  HBC  MOF-1 having three dimensionally connected nanopores.  clearly visualizes that two DEF molecules are adsorbed via multiple CH-π interactions onto the π plane of the HBC moiety in HBCL2. The layered structure of  HBC  MOF-1 was supported by multiple weak interlayer bonds such as (1) CH-π bonds (2.68 and 2.72 Å) between two hydrogen atoms of a benzoate unit in HBCL2 and two aromatic rings of the mesityl groups in HBCL1 in an adjacent layer and (2) a CH-O bond (2.74 Å) between a hydrogen atom in a methyl group of the mesityl unit in HBCL1 and an oxygen atom in the carboxylate group of HBCL1 in an adjacent layer (Figure S11a). The three dimensionally connected nanopores adopt a zigzag shape with maximum and minimum cross sections of 12.9 × 9.3 and 4.3 × 3.3 Å2, respectively (c and Figures S12 and S13). Furthermore, the volume of its solvent-accessible void was calculated to be 19% of the total volume. Interestingly, the large π planes of the HBC moieties in HBCL are not stacked together but exposed to the interior void of the nanopore, where a 1 cm3 single crystal of  HBC  MOF-1 is estimated to provide a total π surface area of 4.5 × 102 m2.

elements.content: Crystal structure of HBC MOF-1: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), and oxygen (red). DEF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Coordination geometry of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit coordinated by four neighboring ligands. Each Zn2+ ion is tetrahedrally coordinated by two crystallographically different ligands, denoted HBCL1 and HBCL2. The red arrows feature an axial rotational freedom of the nanographene units. (b-I) Schematic representation of a single constituent layer of HBC MOF-1 composed of Zn2+ and HBCL, where the HBC units are shown in a CPK model. (b-II) Schematic representation of how the constituent layers are stacked in HBC MOF-1. Adjacent layers are distinguished in gray and orange colors. The mesityl groups are omitted for clarity. Schematic representations of the solvent-accessible surfaces (probe radius 1.4 Å), viewed along the (c-I) a and (c-II) b axes. The 3D pore surfaces are shown in yellow.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of  HBC  MOF-1: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), and oxygen (red). DEF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Coordination geometry of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit coordinated by four neighboring ligands. Each Zn2+ ion is tetrahedrally coordinated by two crystallographically different ligands, denoted HBCL1 and HBCL2. The red arrows feature an axial rotational freedom of the nanographene units. (b-I) Schematic representation of a single constituent layer of  HBC  MOF-1 composed of Zn2+ and HBCL, where the HBC units are shown in a CPK model. (b-II) Schematic representation of how the constituent layers are stacked in  HBC  MOF-1. Adjacent layers are distinguished in gray and orange colors. The mesityl groups are omitted for clarity. Schematic representations of the solvent-accessible surfaces (probe radius 1.4 Å), viewed along the (c-I) a and (c-II) b axes. The 3D pore surfaces are shown in yellow.

elements.content: Schematic representations of the crystal structure of HBC MOF-1 featuring N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) molecules adsorbed via CH−π bonding interactions onto the π surface of HBCL: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), oxygen (red), and hydrogen (white). DEF molecules are shown in green.
elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic representations of the crystal structure of  HBC  MOF-1 featuring N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) molecules adsorbed via CH-π bonding interactions onto the π surface of HBCL: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), oxygen (red), and hydrogen (white). DEF molecules are shown in green.

elements.content: HBC MOF was thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. As shown in Figure S14, HBC MOF-1 in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed a stepwise weight loss upon heating due to the removal of guest molecules (DEF and water), a 25% weight loss in the range of 60–120 °C and a subsequent 5% weight loss up to 180 °C, eventually affording HBC MOF-3, [Zn­(HBCL)­(DEF)] n , with a 1:1 molar ratio of HBCL to DEF. When it was heated at 120 °C for 30 min in air, HBC MOF-1 was converted into single-crystalline HBC MOF-2 with a loss of five DEF molecules per Zn2+ ( and Table S3). This crystalline transition from HBC MOF-1 to HBC MOF-2 was accompanied by a change in coordination geometry of the Zn2+ ions from tetrahedral to trigonal bipyramidal (Figure S8a,c). Nevertheless, analogous to HBC MOF-1, HBC MOF-2 comprises infinite metal–organic layers featuring dinuclear Zn2+ complex units that are located on top of each other (Figures S9b and S10b). Although the nanopores in HBC MOF-1 are three dimensionally interconnected with each other, those in HBC MOF-2 are one-dimensional ().
elements.clean_text: HBC  MOF was thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. As shown in Figure S14,  HBC  MOF-1 in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed a stepwise weight loss upon heating due to the removal of guest molecules (DEF and water), a 25% weight loss in the range of 60-120 °C and a subsequent 5% weight loss up to 180 °C, eventually affording  HBC  MOF-3, [Zn(HBCL)(DEF)] n , with a 1:1 molar ratio of HBCL to DEF. When it was heated at 120 °C for 30 min in air,  HBC  MOF-1 was converted into single-crystalline  HBC  MOF-2 with a loss of five DEF molecules per Zn2+ ( and Table S3). This crystalline transition from  HBC  MOF-1 to  HBC  MOF-2 was accompanied by a change in coordination geometry of the Zn2+ ions from tetrahedral to trigonal bipyramidal (Figure S8a,c). Nevertheless, analogous to  HBC  MOF-1,  HBC  MOF-2 comprises infinite metal-organic layers featuring dinuclear Zn2+ complex units that are located on top of each other (Figures S9b and S10b). Although the nanopores in  HBC  MOF-1 are three dimensionally interconnected with each other, those in  HBC  MOF-2 are one-dimensional ().

elements.content: We prepared HBC MOF-3 by heating HBC MOF-1 at 120 °C for 12 h under reduced pressure () and investigated its gas sorption profiles with CO2 and hydrocarbons, including acetylene (C2H2), propane (C3H8), propylene (C3H6), benzene (C6H6), and cyclohexane (C6H12). As shown in , all of their sorption profiles were reversible with a characteristic hysteresis loop. Except for the case of C6H12 (i, green), the sorption profiles displayed a stepwise feature. For example, when CO2 was utilized as an adsorbate, the adsorption and desorption events both showed a two-step profile with a hysteresis loop in the P/P 0 range of 0.57–0.87 (a). For reference, we tested gas sorption profiles of representative MOFs such as HKUST-1 and MOF-5. However, none of them were hysteretic under the same conditions (Figure S19). We note further that the sorption profiles of the HBC-based rigid MOF with CO2 and N2, reported by Zhou et al., were not hysteretic. In general, such stepwise and hysteretic gas sorption profiles are typically observable for 3D MOFs with interpenetrated movable structures but have rarely been reported for 2D MOFs such as HBC MOF. In relation to this notion, we measured powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of HBC MOF-3, which had been exposed beforehand to the above six gases at their saturated vapor pressures and compared them with the PXRD profile of intact HBC MOF-3. As shown in j, there were no pairs of identical PXRD patterns. We suppose that, in these peculiar observations, a possible rotational freedom of the constituent nanographene sheets and their particular π-electronic nature play an essential role.
elements.clean_text: We prepared  HBC  MOF-3 by heating  HBC  MOF-1 at 120 °C for 12 h under reduced pressure () and investigated its gas sorption profiles with CO2 and hydrocarbons, including acetylene (C2H2), propane (C3H8), propylene (C3H6), benzene (C6H6), and cyclohexane (C6H12). As shown in , all of their sorption profiles were reversible with a characteristic hysteresis loop. Except for the case of C6H12 (i, green), the sorption profiles displayed a stepwise feature. For example, when CO2 was utilized as an adsorbate, the adsorption and desorption events both showed a two-step profile with a hysteresis loop in the P/P 0 range of 0.57-0.87 (a). For reference, we tested gas sorption profiles of representative MOFs such as HKUST-1 and MOF-5. However, none of them were hysteretic under the same conditions (Figure S19). We note further that the sorption profiles of the HBC-based rigid MOF with CO2 and N2, reported by Zhou et al., were not hysteretic. In general, such stepwise and hysteretic gas sorption profiles are typically observable for 3D MOFs with interpenetrated movable structures but have rarely been reported for 2D MOFs such as  HBC  MOF. In relation to this notion, we measured powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of  HBC  MOF-3, which had been exposed beforehand to the above six gases at their saturated vapor pressures and compared them with the PXRD profile of intact  HBC  MOF-3. As shown in j, there were no pairs of identical PXRD patterns. We suppose that, in these peculiar observations, a possible rotational freedom of the constituent nanographene sheets and their particular π-electronic nature play an essential role.

elements.content: Sorption isotherms of (a) CO2 (195 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (c) C2H2 (189 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (e) C3H8 (231 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (g) C3H6 (226 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), and (i) benzene (C6H6, black, 288 K, P 0 = 7.8 kPa) and cyclohexane (C6H12, green, 288 K, P 0 = 8.1 kPa) on HBC MOF-3. Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively. PXRD patterns measured at each equilibrium point in the (b) CO2, (d) C2H2, (f) C3H8, and (h) C3H6 sorption isotherms. (j) PXRD patterns measured at P/P 0 = 1.0 in the sorption isotherms of CO2 (red, 195 K), C2H2 (blue, 189 K), C3H8 (orange, 231 K), C3H6 (purple, 226 K), C6H6 (black, 298 K), and C6H12 (green, 298 K), respectively, on HBC MOF-3. The PXRD pattern denoted with HBC MOF-3 was measured under ambient conditions before the sorption experiments. (k)–(m) Gas chromatograms for C2H2/CO2 gas mixtures before (feed gas, black) and after (adsorbed gas, red) the sorption on HBC MOF-3. Feed gas mixtures with three different C2H2/CO2 ratios were used: (k) 70/30, (l) 50/50, and (m) 30/70. In all cases, C2H2 was preferentially adsorbed over CO2 on HBC MOF-3.
elements.clean_text: 5  Sorption isotherms of (a) CO2 (195 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (c) C2H2 (189 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (e) C3H8 (231 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (g) C3H6 (226 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), and (i) benzene (C6H6, black, 288 K, P 0 = 7.8 kPa) and cyclohexane (C6H12, green, 288 K, P 0 = 8.1 kPa) on  HBC  MOF-3. Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively. PXRD patterns measured at each equilibrium point in the (b) CO2, (d) C2H2, (f) C3H8, and (h) C3H6 sorption isotherms. (j) PXRD patterns measured at P/P 0 = 1.0 in the sorption isotherms of CO2 (red, 195 K), C2H2 (blue, 189 K), C3H8 (orange, 231 K), C3H6 (purple, 226 K), C6H6 (black, 298 K), and C6H12 (green, 298 K), respectively, on  HBC  MOF-3. The PXRD pattern denoted with  HBC  MOF-3 was measured under ambient conditions before the sorption experiments. (k)-(m) Gas chromatograms for C2H2/CO2 gas mixtures before (feed gas, black) and after (adsorbed gas, red) the sorption on  HBC  MOF-3. Feed gas mixtures with three different C2H2/CO2 ratios were used: (k) 70/30, (l) 50/50, and (m) 30/70. In all cases, C2H2 was preferentially adsorbed over CO2 on  HBC  MOF-3.

elements.content: From the adsorption isotherms in , we estimated the maximum amounts of CO2 (6.7 mmol g–1) and hydrocarbons such as C2H2 (15.4 mmol g–1, Table S8), C3H8 (8.3 mmol g–1), C3H6 (9.4 mmol g–1), C6H6 (6.5 mmol g–1), and C6H12 (4.5 mmol g–1) adsorbed onto HBC MOF-3. These values allowed us to calculate the pore volumes for CO2 and the examined hydrocarbons as 0.29 and 0.49–0.64 mL g–1, respectively (Table S6). The results suggest that HBC MOF-3 has the least affinity toward CO2 but more affinity toward other gaseous molecules that can interact with nanographenes via a π–π interaction or a CH−π interaction. It is worth noting that the maximum amount of C2H2 adsorbed onto HBC MOF-3 is 2.3 times larger than that of CO2. Such an unprecedentedly high C2H2/CO2 ratio at P/P 0 = 1.0 (Table S7) is important for the efficient purification and storage of C2H2. Indeed, gas separation experiments using C2H2/CO2 mixtures upon adsorption on HBC MOF showed a content of C2H2 higher than that in the feed irrespective of their compositions of 70/30, 50/50, and 30/70 (k–m).
elements.clean_text: From the adsorption isotherms in , we estimated the maximum amounts of CO2 (6.7 mmol g-1) and hydrocarbons such as C2H2 (15.4 mmol g-1, Table S8), C3H8 (8.3 mmol g-1), C3H6 (9.4 mmol g-1), C6H6 (6.5 mmol g-1), and C6H12 (4.5 mmol g-1) adsorbed onto  HBC  MOF-3. These values allowed us to calculate the pore volumes for CO2 and the examined hydrocarbons as 0.29 and 0.49-0.64 mL g-1, respectively (Table S6). The results suggest that  HBC  MOF-3 has the least affinity toward CO2 but more affinity toward other gaseous molecules that can interact with nanographenes via a π-π interaction or a CH-π interaction. It is worth noting that the maximum amount of C2H2 adsorbed onto  HBC  MOF-3 is 2.3 times larger than that of CO2. Such an unprecedentedly high C2H2/CO2 ratio at P/P 0 = 1.0 (Table S7) is important for the efficient purification and storage of C2H2. Indeed, gas separation experiments using C2H2/CO2 mixtures upon adsorption on  HBC  MOF showed a content of C2H2 higher than that in the feed irrespective of their compositions of 70/30, 50/50, and 30/70 (k-m).

elements.content: As described above, the sorption profiles of all six gases were reversible (), and except for C6H12 (i, green), they were stepwise, suggesting that HBC MOF-3 underwent a pressure-dependent structural phase transition. In relation to this interesting possibility, we measured in situ PXRD patterns of HBC MOF-3 upon sorption of CO2 (195 K, b) and C2H2 (189 K, d). When CO2 was used as an adsorbate, the diffraction peaks showed discontinuous shifts at the steps observed at P/P 0 = 0.87 and 0.57 in the adsorption and desorption events, respectively. In comparison with CO2, C2H2 showed more complicated sorption isotherms, featuring three-step adsorption and desorption profiles (c). Nevertheless, analogous to the case of CO2, the sorption of C2H2 was accompanied by discontinuous shifts of the diffraction peaks at the steps observed at P/P 0 = 0.11, 0.58 (adsorption) and 0.52, 0.28 (desorption) (d).
elements.clean_text: As described above, the sorption profiles of all six gases were reversible (), and except for C6H12 (i, green), they were stepwise, suggesting that  HBC  MOF-3 underwent a pressure-dependent structural phase transition. In relation to this interesting possibility, we measured in situ PXRD patterns of  HBC  MOF-3 upon sorption of CO2 (195 K, b) and C2H2 (189 K, d). When CO2 was used as an adsorbate, the diffraction peaks showed discontinuous shifts at the steps observed at P/P 0 = 0.87 and 0.57 in the adsorption and desorption events, respectively. In comparison with CO2, C2H2 showed more complicated sorption isotherms, featuring three-step adsorption and desorption profiles (c). Nevertheless, analogous to the case of CO2, the sorption of C2H2 was accompanied by discontinuous shifts of the diffraction peaks at the steps observed at P/P 0 = 0.11, 0.58 (adsorption) and 0.52, 0.28 (desorption) (d).

elements.content: From the Le Bail fitting of the PXRD patterns of HBC MOF-3 before and after the adsorption of CO2, we successfully obtained its lattice parameters (Table S5) at P/P 0 = 0 and 0.95. The interlayer distances of 8.21 and 7.83 Å, respectively, calculated from those parameters allowed us to exclude the possibility that the stepwise feature of the sorption of CO2 (a) is due to the interlayer expansion of HBC MOF-3. The same was true for the adsorption of C2H2, where the interlayer distances at P/P 0 = 0 and 0.95 were 8.21 and 7.93 Å, respectively (Table S5). As described above, HBC MOF-3 can adsorb C2H2 2.3 times larger in volume in comparison to CO2. Of interest, the adsorption of such a large volume of C2H2 is possible without an interlayer expansion. This may certainly represent the adaptive nature of HBC MOF-3, where the large nanographene sheets that constitute the MOF framework possibly rotate to lower the condensation energy of an adsorbate.
elements.clean_text: From the Le Bail fitting of the PXRD patterns of  HBC  MOF-3 before and after the adsorption of CO2, we successfully obtained its lattice parameters (Table S5) at P/P 0 = 0 and 0.95. The interlayer distances of 8.21 and 7.83 Å, respectively, calculated from those parameters allowed us to exclude the possibility that the stepwise feature of the sorption of CO2 (a) is due to the interlayer expansion of  HBC  MOF-3. The same was true for the adsorption of C2H2, where the interlayer distances at P/P 0 = 0 and 0.95 were 8.21 and 7.93 Å, respectively (Table S5). As described above,  HBC  MOF-3 can adsorb C2H2 2.3 times larger in volume in comparison to CO2. Of interest, the adsorption of such a large volume of C2H2 is possible without an interlayer expansion. This may certainly represent the adaptive nature of  HBC  MOF-3, where the large nanographene sheets that constitute the MOF framework possibly rotate to lower the condensation energy of an adsorbate.

elements.content: Computational studies also supported the adaptive nature of HBC MOF-3 upon gas sorption. We conducted density functional tight-binding (DFTB) calculations to optimize the structures of HBC MOF-3 with and without adsorbed C2H2 (a,b) and CO2 (c,d) molecules. The results clearly indicate that the HBC moieties in HBC MOF-3 rotate upon gas adsorption. Furthermore, DFTB molecular dynamics simulation studies indicated that a majority of the adsorbed C2H2 molecules align vertically to the HBC π surfaces due to a CH−π bonding interaction (Figure S18a), while none of the CO2 molecules, as expected, align vertically to the π surfaces (Figure S18b).
elements.clean_text: Computational studies also supported the adaptive nature of  HBC  MOF-3 upon gas sorption. We conducted density functional tight-binding (DFTB) calculations to optimize the structures of  HBC  MOF-3 with and without adsorbed C2H2 (a,b) and CO2 (c,d) molecules. The results clearly indicate that the HBC moieties in  HBC  MOF-3 rotate upon gas adsorption. Furthermore, DFTB molecular dynamics simulation studies indicated that a majority of the adsorbed C2H2 molecules align vertically to the HBC π surfaces due to a CH-π bonding interaction (Figure S18a), while none of the CO2 molecules, as expected, align vertically to the π surfaces (Figure S18b).

elements.content: Computational studies on the structural transformations of the HBCL1 and HBCL2 moieties in HBC MOF-3 upon adsorption of (a), (b) C2H2 and (c), (d) CO2. Dihedral angles are defined as shown in the broken square. Green HBCL1 and HBCL2 are before the incorporation of gases, while those in blue and red are after the incorporation of C2H2 and CO2, respectively. For a better understanding of the relative structural transformations, the phenylene rings in the HBCL moieties in question are arbitrarily overlapped as shown in the broken circles. Zn2+ ions are shown in a ball model. Mesityl groups and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 6  Computational studies on the structural transformations of the HBCL1 and HBCL2 moieties in  HBC  MOF-3 upon adsorption of (a), (b) C2H2 and (c), (d) CO2. Dihedral angles are defined as shown in the broken square. Green HBCL1 and HBCL2 are before the incorporation of gases, while those in blue and red are after the incorporation of C2H2 and CO2, respectively. For a better understanding of the relative structural transformations, the phenylene rings in the HBCL moieties in question are arbitrarily overlapped as shown in the broken circles. Zn2+ ions are shown in a ball model. Mesityl groups and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: It is now clear from j and and Figure S18 that the structures of HBC MOF-3 including the geometry and deformation of the HBC units, filled with and without gaseous molecules, are very different from each other. This indicates that the gaseous molecules, on incorporation into the HBC MOF-3 nanopores, eventually fix relative geometries of the HBC units due to their strong interaction with the gaseous molecules. Hence, even when the applied gas pressure is reduced to some extent, the HBC units may not be allowed to change their geometries once fixed because of a large activation barrier for the recovery of the original structure. Consequently, a hysteretic sorption profile emerges. This remarkable hysteresis, widely observed for many different gaseous molecules, may originate from the large π surface area of the HBC units.
elements.clean_text: It is now clear from j and  and Figure S18 that the structures of  HBC  MOF-3 including the geometry and deformation of the HBC units, filled with and without gaseous molecules, are very different from each other. This indicates that the gaseous molecules, on incorporation into the  HBC  MOF-3 nanopores, eventually fix relative geometries of the HBC units due to their strong interaction with the gaseous molecules. Hence, even when the applied gas pressure is reduced to some extent, the HBC units may not be allowed to change their geometries once fixed because of a large activation barrier for the recovery of the original structure. Consequently, a hysteretic sorption profile emerges. This remarkable hysteresis, widely observed for many different gaseous molecules, may originate from the large π surface area of the HBC units.

elements.content: As shown in e,g, other hydrocarbons such as C3H8 and C3H6 also afforded stepwise and hysteretic sorption isotherms on HBC MOF-3, accompanied by discontinuous shifts of the diffraction peaks in their PXRD profiles (f,h). These results clearly indicate that HBC MOF-3 is intrinsically adaptive upon gas sorption due to the axial rotational freedom of its HBC units.
elements.clean_text: As shown in e,g, other hydrocarbons such as C3H8 and C3H6 also afforded stepwise and hysteretic sorption isotherms on  HBC  MOF-3, accompanied by discontinuous shifts of the diffraction peaks in their PXRD profiles (f,h). These results clearly indicate that  HBC  MOF-3 is intrinsically adaptive upon gas sorption due to the axial rotational freedom of its HBC units.

elements.content: In conclusion, we succeeded in the one-step synthesis of a novel nanographene MOF ( HBC MOF) by combining with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O a high-solubility HBC ligand carrying at its periphery four mesityl groups and two 4-carboxyphenyl functionalities. In contrast with the rigid HBC-based MOF recently reported, HBC MOF can be characterized by an adaptive nature due to the axial rotational freedom of its HBC units. Possibly due to the extra-large π surface area, HBC MOF is affinitive toward adsorbates that are capable of π–π and/or CH−π interactions such as C2H2, C3H8, C3H6, C6H6, and C6H12 but has less affinity toward CO2. Notably, the sorption isotherms of HBC MOF with these adsorbates commonly displayed a clear hysteretic profile. Except for the case of C6H12, their sorption events occur in a stepwise fashion due to pressure-dependent structural phase transitions. These observations suggest that our HBC MOF is located on an opposite extreme of the rigid species reported by Zhou et al. We anticipate that these rigid and flexible nanocarbon analogues may open new possibilities of porous materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we succeeded in the one-step synthesis of a novel nanographene MOF ( HBC  MOF) by combining with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O a high-solubility HBC ligand carrying at its periphery four mesityl groups and two 4-carboxyphenyl functionalities. In contrast with the rigid HBC-based MOF recently reported,  HBC  MOF can be characterized by an adaptive nature due to the axial rotational freedom of its HBC units. Possibly due to the extra-large π surface area,  HBC  MOF is affinitive toward adsorbates that are capable of π-π and/or CH-π interactions such as C2H2, C3H8, C3H6, C6H6, and C6H12 but has less affinity toward CO2. Notably, the sorption isotherms of  HBC  MOF with these adsorbates commonly displayed a clear hysteretic profile. Except for the case of C6H12, their sorption events occur in a stepwise fashion due to pressure-dependent structural phase transitions. These observations suggest that our  HBC  MOF is located on an opposite extreme of the rigid species reported by Zhou et al. We anticipate that these rigid and flexible nanocarbon analogues may open new possibilities of porous materials.

cln_elements.content: HBC MOF was thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. As shown in Figure S14, HBC MOF-1 in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed a stepwise weight loss upon heating due to the removal of guest molecules (DEF and water), a 25% weight loss in the range of 60–120 °C and a subsequent 5% weight loss up to 180 °C, eventually affording HBC MOF-3, [Zn­(HBCL)­(DEF)] n , with a 1:1 molar ratio of HBCL to DEF. When it was heated at 120 °C for 30 min in air, HBC MOF-1 was converted into single-crystalline HBC MOF-2 with a loss of five DEF molecules per Zn2+ ( and Table S3). This crystalline transition from HBC MOF-1 to HBC MOF-2 was accompanied by a change in coordination geometry of the Zn2+ ions from tetrahedral to trigonal bipyramidal (Figure S8a,c). Nevertheless, analogous to HBC MOF-1, HBC MOF-2 comprises infinite metal–organic layers featuring dinuclear Zn2+ complex units that are located on top of each other (Figures S9b and S10b). Although the nanopores in HBC MOF-1 are three dimensionally interconnected with each other, those in HBC MOF-2 are one-dimensional ().
cln_elements.clean_text: HBC  MOF was thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. As shown in Figure S14,  HBC  MOF-1 in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed a stepwise weight loss upon heating due to the removal of guest molecules (DEF and water), a 25% weight loss in the range of 60-120 °C and a subsequent 5% weight loss up to 180 °C, eventually affording  HBC  MOF-3, [Zn(HBCL)(DEF)] n , with a 1:1 molar ratio of HBCL to DEF. When it was heated at 120 °C for 30 min in air,  HBC  MOF-1 was converted into single-crystalline  HBC  MOF-2 with a loss of five DEF molecules per Zn2+ ( and Table S3). This crystalline transition from  HBC  MOF-1 to  HBC  MOF-2 was accompanied by a change in coordination geometry of the Zn2+ ions from tetrahedral to trigonal bipyramidal (Figure S8a,c). Nevertheless, analogous to  HBC  MOF-1,  HBC  MOF-2 comprises infinite metal-organic layers featuring dinuclear Zn2+ complex units that are located on top of each other (Figures S9b and S10b). Although the nanopores in  HBC  MOF-1 are three dimensionally interconnected with each other, those in  HBC  MOF-2 are one-dimensional ().

data.type: 25% weight loss due to removal of guest molecules
conversion of HBC MOF-1 to HBC MOF-2

cln_elements.content: Synthetic scheme for a HBC-based ligand (HBCLH2). Top and side views of the X-ray crystal structure of HBCLH2 are shown next to its chemical structure. The thermal ellipsoids are scaled to the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms in the top and side views and the mesityl groups in the side view are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic scheme for a HBC-based ligand (HBCLH2). Top and side views of the X-ray crystal structure of HBCLH2 are shown next to its chemical structure. The thermal ellipsoids are scaled to the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms in the top and side views and the mesityl groups in the side view are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Synthetic scheme for HBC MOFs using Zn2+ and HBCLH2. A microscopic image features a single crystal of HBC MOF-1. HBC MOF-1, HBC MOF-2, and HBC MOF-3 are interconvertible upon removal and uptake of guest molecules (DEF and water). DEF denotes N,N-diethylformamide.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Synthetic scheme for  HBC  MOFs using Zn2+ and HBCLH2. A microscopic image features a single crystal of  HBC  MOF-1.  HBC  MOF-1,  HBC  MOF-2, and  HBC  MOF-3 are interconvertible upon removal and uptake of guest molecules (DEF and water). DEF denotes N,N-diethylformamide.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of HBC MOF-1: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), and oxygen (red). DEF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Coordination geometry of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit coordinated by four neighboring ligands. Each Zn2+ ion is tetrahedrally coordinated by two crystallographically different ligands, denoted HBCL1 and HBCL2. The red arrows feature an axial rotational freedom of the nanographene units. (b-I) Schematic representation of a single constituent layer of HBC MOF-1 composed of Zn2+ and HBCL, where the HBC units are shown in a CPK model. (b-II) Schematic representation of how the constituent layers are stacked in HBC MOF-1. Adjacent layers are distinguished in gray and orange colors. The mesityl groups are omitted for clarity. Schematic representations of the solvent-accessible surfaces (probe radius 1.4 Å), viewed along the (c-I) a and (c-II) b axes. The 3D pore surfaces are shown in yellow.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of  HBC  MOF-1: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), and oxygen (red). DEF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Coordination geometry of a dinuclear Zn2+ complex unit coordinated by four neighboring ligands. Each Zn2+ ion is tetrahedrally coordinated by two crystallographically different ligands, denoted HBCL1 and HBCL2. The red arrows feature an axial rotational freedom of the nanographene units. (b-I) Schematic representation of a single constituent layer of  HBC  MOF-1 composed of Zn2+ and HBCL, where the HBC units are shown in a CPK model. (b-II) Schematic representation of how the constituent layers are stacked in  HBC  MOF-1. Adjacent layers are distinguished in gray and orange colors. The mesityl groups are omitted for clarity. Schematic representations of the solvent-accessible surfaces (probe radius 1.4 Å), viewed along the (c-I) a and (c-II) b axes. The 3D pore surfaces are shown in yellow.

cln_elements.content: Schematic representations of the crystal structure of HBC MOF-1 featuring N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) molecules adsorbed via CH−π bonding interactions onto the π surface of HBCL: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), oxygen (red), and hydrogen (white). DEF molecules are shown in green.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic representations of the crystal structure of  HBC  MOF-1 featuring N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) molecules adsorbed via CH-π bonding interactions onto the π surface of HBCL: zinc (purple), carbon (gray), oxygen (red), and hydrogen (white). DEF molecules are shown in green.

cln_elements.content: Sorption isotherms of (a) CO2 (195 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (c) C2H2 (189 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (e) C3H8 (231 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (g) C3H6 (226 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), and (i) benzene (C6H6, black, 288 K, P 0 = 7.8 kPa) and cyclohexane (C6H12, green, 288 K, P 0 = 8.1 kPa) on HBC MOF-3. Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively. PXRD patterns measured at each equilibrium point in the (b) CO2, (d) C2H2, (f) C3H8, and (h) C3H6 sorption isotherms. (j) PXRD patterns measured at P/P 0 = 1.0 in the sorption isotherms of CO2 (red, 195 K), C2H2 (blue, 189 K), C3H8 (orange, 231 K), C3H6 (purple, 226 K), C6H6 (black, 298 K), and C6H12 (green, 298 K), respectively, on HBC MOF-3. The PXRD pattern denoted with HBC MOF-3 was measured under ambient conditions before the sorption experiments. (k)–(m) Gas chromatograms for C2H2/CO2 gas mixtures before (feed gas, black) and after (adsorbed gas, red) the sorption on HBC MOF-3. Feed gas mixtures with three different C2H2/CO2 ratios were used: (k) 70/30, (l) 50/50, and (m) 30/70. In all cases, C2H2 was preferentially adsorbed over CO2 on HBC MOF-3.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Sorption isotherms of (a) CO2 (195 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (c) C2H2 (189 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (e) C3H8 (231 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), (g) C3H6 (226 K, P 0 = 101.3 kPa), and (i) benzene (C6H6, black, 288 K, P 0 = 7.8 kPa) and cyclohexane (C6H12, green, 288 K, P 0 = 8.1 kPa) on  HBC  MOF-3. Closed and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively. PXRD patterns measured at each equilibrium point in the (b) CO2, (d) C2H2, (f) C3H8, and (h) C3H6 sorption isotherms. (j) PXRD patterns measured at P/P 0 = 1.0 in the sorption isotherms of CO2 (red, 195 K), C2H2 (blue, 189 K), C3H8 (orange, 231 K), C3H6 (purple, 226 K), C6H6 (black, 298 K), and C6H12 (green, 298 K), respectively, on  HBC  MOF-3. The PXRD pattern denoted with  HBC  MOF-3 was measured under ambient conditions before the sorption experiments. (k)-(m) Gas chromatograms for C2H2/CO2 gas mixtures before (feed gas, black) and after (adsorbed gas, red) the sorption on  HBC  MOF-3. Feed gas mixtures with three different C2H2/CO2 ratios were used: (k) 70/30, (l) 50/50, and (m) 30/70. In all cases, C2H2 was preferentially adsorbed over CO2 on  HBC  MOF-3.

metadata.title:
One-Step
Synthesis of an Adaptive Nanographene MOF:
Adsorbed Gas-Dependent Geometrical Diversity
